channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: First Captives Freed in Tense Gaza Truce Between Israel and Hamas
item.description: Hamas freed two dozen hostages, Israel released 39 imprisoned Palestinians, and more than 130 aid trucks reached Gaza over the first day of a tense, temporary truce after seven weeks of war.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Christina Goldbaum, Rami Nazzal and Alan Yuhas
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: International Red Cross vehicles at the Gaza border with Egypt on Friday, said to be carrying hostages freed by Hamas.

item.title: ‘It Snowballed:’ How a Knife Attack in Dublin Led to a Riot
item.description: The violence in Ireland’s capital on Thursday night was fueled by far-right agitators who spread rumors online about an attack on three children earlier that day.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Adam Satariano
item.media:description: Riot police officers by a burning car in Dublin late Thursday.

item.title: Israelis Welcome Some Hostages Home, In a Poignant Moment
item.description: The return of 13 Israeli hostages out of more than 200 provided a glimmer of hope for a nation still traumatized by the Hamas assault of Oct. 7.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: A helicopter with released hostages at the landing pad of Schneider hospital in Petah Tikva, Israel, on Friday.

item.title: In West Bank, Relief Over Prisoners’ Release Is Tempered by Worries About War
item.description: Families that waited outside a prison for the release of people detained by Israel said the conflict in Gaza and the rising death toll had cast a pall over any celebration.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Rami Nazzal
item.media:description: Celebrating the release of Palestinian prisoners outside the West Bank city of Ramallah on Friday.

item.title: Argentina’s Economy Depends on the U.S. Dollar. Can Javier Milei Change That?
item.description: Years of economic quagmire created an upside-down economy in Argentina. Javier Milei, a far-right populist, won the presidency this week by promising to blow it all up.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, Natalie Alcoba and Lucía Cholakian Herrera
item.media:credit: Anita Pouchard Serra for The New York Times
item.media:description: A shop in Buenos Aires, where prices are often written in chalk to allow for frequent increases.

item.title: Taiwan’s Opposition Splits After Collapse of Unity Bid
item.description: The split over a proposed joint ticket bolsters the governing party candidate’s chances in the coming presidential election. That won’t please Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: From left to right: Terry Gou, a presidential candidate; former President Ma Ying-jeou of Taiwan; and Hou Yu-ih, a presidential candidate of the opposition party Kuomintang, at a meeting open to journalists in Taiwan on Thursday.

item.title: As Cease-Fire Takes Hold, Some Gazans Attempt a Treacherous Return Home
item.description: Israel had warned Gazans not to move from the south to the north during the cessation of hostilities, feeding their fears of permanent displacement.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Ameera Harouda
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Displaced Palestinians trying to return to Gaza City in the north on Friday during a pause in the conflict.

item.title: Can the Palestinian Authority Really Govern Gaza After the War?
item.description: Considered authoritarian and corrupt, the Palestinian Authority is still Washington’s choice to run the enclave. But many believe it can be credible now only if it includes Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gaza City. Hamas seized control of Gaza in 2007, after winning legislative elections the previous year.

item.title: For Monetochka, a Moral Stand Started a Creative Climb
item.description: Monetochka was one of Russia’s most discussed pop stars. Now, like other antiwar acts in exile, she’s having to retool her career.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne and Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Marvin Zilm for The New York Times
item.media:description: Monetochka performing in Zurich this month.

item.title: Once a Homeless Addict, a Mayor Takes On Housing and Drug Crises
item.description: Dan Carter was on the streets for 17 years. His experience informs his policy agenda as mayor of Oshawa, Ontario, a city of 175,000 struggling with overdoses and affordability.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Dan Carter at city hall in Oshawa, Ontario. Homeless and addicted to drugs from his teenage years until he was 31, he was fired from more jobs than he could remember.

item.title: Illness Surge in China Is Not From a Novel Pathogen, Data Suggests
item.description: The W.H.O. had requested detailed information about a reported surge in respiratory illnesses in children in China. Chinese data suggested the surge was caused by known bacteria and viruses.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: Children receiving intravenous drips at a hospital in Beijing on Thursday.

item.title: North Korea’s Han Kwang-song Returns to International Soccer
item.description: Han Kwang-song’s recent appearances in World Cup qualifiers were his first ones overseas since 2020, when U.N. sanctions led to an involuntary career break.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and John Yoon
item.media:description: Han Kwang-song of North Korea, center, playing in a 2026 World Cup qualifier in Yangon, Myanmar, this week.

item.title: Baseball Has Grown in Bogotá, Colombia, Thanks to Venezuelan Migrants
item.description: In a Bogotá league, Venezuelans who fled their homeland have carried on their culture in a country surrounded by soccer — and have built a support system. “It’s like having a piece of Venezuela here.”
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Jaír Coll for The New York Times
item.media:description: Boys from the Leones baseball team at the Hermes Barros Cabas baseball stadium in Bogotá.

item.title: India Faces Questions About Another Reported Foreign Assassination Plot
item.description: The U.S., while not publicly accusing New Delhi of trying to orchestrate a killing on American soil, said it had expressed concern to Indian officials.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India and President Biden in Washington in June. News outlets reported on Wednesday that the Biden administration had told the Indian government it had information possibly linking New Delhi to an assassination plot.

item.title: Waiting Continues For Families of American Hostages in Gaza
item.description: No Americans were released in the first day of the temporary cease-fire, but officials and families were hopeful they would be freed in the coming days.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:description: President Biden called the release “the start of a process” and expected more hostages to be freed on Saturday and the days after.

item.title: 12 People Taken Hostage from Kibbutz Nir Oz Return to Israel
item.description: Of the 13 Israeli hostages released from Gaza on Friday night, 12 were from a single farming village: Kibbutz Nir Oz.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli soldier looks inside a house that was attacked by Hamas militants on Oct. 7 in Kibbutz Nir Oz, Israel, late last month.

item.title: Who the Released Israeli Hostages Are
item.description: The first group of 13 Israeli hostages — all women and children — were handed over to Israeli officials on Friday, joining five others released or rescued earlier in the fighting.
item.dc:creator: Nadav Gavrielov, Isabel Kershner, Adam Sella, Gaya Gupta, Talya Minsberg and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A display in Tel Aviv of photos of Israeli citizens held hostage in Gaza.

item.title: Audrey Salkeld, Pioneering Historian of Everest, Dies at 87
item.description: She trawled 56 boxes of forgotten archives, bringing to life mysterious figures from early expeditions. She also climbed Everest, as well as Kilimanjaro.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter

item.title: The Premier League Needs a Commissioner
item.description: Allowing clubs to block rule changes and money to delay punishments feeds the perception that the same rules do not apply to everyone.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: The richest prize money can buy.

item.title: Iceland in Limbo Despite Threat of Volcanic Eruption Being Lowered
item.description: A fishing town that was evacuated this month will probably be spared, but residents can’t return until all danger has passed.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Grindavik, Iceland, was evacuated this month because of volcanic activity.

item.title: Oscar Pistorius, Olympic Athlete Convicted of Murder, to Be Paroled
item.description: The South African sprinter, who garnered global headlines after killing his girlfriend in 2013, will be released in January after meeting the requirements for parole.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius arriving at the Pretoria High Court in 2016. A parole board granted Mr. Pistorius’s petition for parole on the basis that he had served half of his 15-year sentence.

item.title: Past Israel-Hamas Cease-Fires Have Proved Fragile
item.description: In 2014, nine truces came and went during a 51-day conflict and more than 2,000 people were killed before there was a lasting agreement to halt the fighting.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Artillery shells of the Israeli Army at the border with Gaza during the 11-day conflict between Israel and Hamas, in 2021.

item.title: Cheers for Cricket
item.description: How sports can dissolve boundaries.
item.dc:creator: Vivek Shankar
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: The celebration after Australia beat India to win the Cricket World Cup.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A family fleeing after an Israeli strike in Rafah on Thursday.

item.title: Israel, Hamas Agree to Begin Cease-Fire Friday Morning
item.description: Prodded by the U.S., Israel agreed to the pause in hostilities and the release of 150 imprisoned Palestinians in exchange for 50 hostages held in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Hiba Yazbek and Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: The relatives of children kidnapped on Oct. 7, along with families and supporters of hostages, protesting on Monday in Tel Aviv.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Gaza Cease-Fire to Begin Today
item.description: Plus a surge in respiratory illnesses in China.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: The scene of an Israeli strike in Rafah on Thursday.

item.title: What’s in the Israel-Hamas Cease-Fire and Hostage Release Deal
item.description: Officials in Qatar, which helped broker the deal, said 13 hostages were expected to be released on Friday. An Israeli official said Palestinians in Israel’s custody would be freed first.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick, Aaron Boxerman and Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Flour being distributed in Khan Younis, in southern Gaza, on Wednesday. A temporary cease-fire between Israel and Hamas was expected to take effect on Friday.

item.title: Rioters Clash With Police in Dublin After Children Are Hurt in Knife Attack
item.description: A suspect was in custody after a woman and three children were injured in the Irish capital. After the incident, riots that the police said were driven by “misinformation” about the attack erupted.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Riot police officers by a burning car in Dublin late Thursday.

item.title: Families in the West Bank Eagerly Await a Prisoner Release
item.description: The announcement that an exchange of hostages for prisoners would begin on Friday lifted the hopes of many Palestinians whose relatives are in Israeli jails.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: The family of Walaa Tanji, who was detained by Israel over a year ago, is hoping to welcome her home soon in the Balata refugee camp on the outskirts of Nablus in the West Bank.

item.title: Dutch Election Results Deliver a Turn to the Far Right
item.description: In an election result that sent shock waves across Europe, Geert Wilders, a longtime far-right provocateur, is closer than ever to becoming prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Geert Wilders has long been a far-right opposition candidate. Now he is poised to lead the largest party in the Dutch House of Representatives.

item.title: Finland Steps Up Border Closings in Dispute With Russia
item.description: The escalation comes as Finland tries to address a rise in the arrivals of migrants and asylum seekers that officials blame on Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Johanna Lemola and Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Finnish border guards escorting migrants at the international crossing with Russia near Salla, Finland, on Thursday.

item.title: U.K. Net Migration Numbers Hit a Record, Embarrassing Conservatives
item.description: The governing Conservative Party has long promised to reduce arrivals. It said Brexit would help. But the numbers in 2022 were the highest ever.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Even before the latest figures, Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain had said that the immigration numbers were “too high, it’s as simple as that.”

item.title: East Africa Floods: Torrential Rain and Floods Wreak Havoc
item.description: The deluges have caused deaths and displacement in a region still reeling from its worst drought in four decades.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: A woman trying to collect some belongings from her home in Garissa, Kenya, after flooding.

item.title: More Than 100 Bodies Are Delivered to a Mass Grave in Southern Gaza
item.description: In Khan Younis, 111 bodies wrapped in bright blue bags arrived in a shipping container on the back of a truck.
item.dc:creator: Yousef Masoud and Daniel Victor
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times

item.title: South Korea Sentences Dissident Who Fled China on a Jet Ski
item.description: Kwon Pyong made the 200-mile journey in August in a bid for asylum. His worst nightmare was being sent back to China, a fellow activist said.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young

item.title: Putin Eyes Another Term as President, With War as Backdrop
item.description: There is little doubt about the outcome, should he run, but the election in March carries more significance as the first one since the invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A photograph provided by the Russian state news media showing President Vladimir V. Putin at his inauguration ceremony in 2018.

item.title: Olympic Truce for Paris 2024 Collides With Reality
item.description: Amid two prominent wars and other conflicts around the globe, a biennial call at the United Nations for peace during the Games felt even more symbolic than usual.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Keh
item.media:description: The International Olympic Committee president, Thomas Bach, making the case at the United Nations on Tuesday for peace during the Games.

item.title: Relatives of Those Stuck in Gaza Face Guilt and Fear
item.description: “When it comes to food, when it comes to freedom,” said one Washington resident whose brother is trapped in the besieged enclave, “the feeling of guilt is killing me.”
item.dc:creator: Rachel Abrams
item.media:description: Mohammed Salah Arafat looking out at the Capitol from the rooftop of his apartment complex. He is a Washington, D.C., resident whose family is still in Gaza.

item.title: W.H.O. Asks China for Details on Surge of Respiratory Illness in Children
item.description: Reports of overcrowding at pediatric hospitals in China have raised concerns about a jump in respiratory illnesses affecting children.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Siyi Zhao
item.category: Children's Hospital of Capital Institute of Pediatrics (Beijing, China)
item.media:description: Children and their parents waiting at an outpatient area at a children hospital in Beijing on Thursday. The World Health Organization has asked China on Thursday for more data on a respiratory illness spreading in the north of the country, urging people to take steps to reduce the risk of infection.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: The intricacies of a hostage deal between Israel and Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: An Israeli tank heads toward the Gaza Strip.

item.title: As Pakistan Expels Afghan Migrants, Families Are Ripped Apart
item.description: Husbands and wives, parents and children, wonder when, or if, they will ever see each other again.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:credit: Insiya Syed for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ram Bibi, the wife of Baz Gul, an Afghan migrant who was arrested and later deported from Pakistan.

item.title: White House Eyes Possible Threat to Good Friday Agreement
item.description: Biden administration officials are watching whether the British government’s attempt to salvage its Rwanda asylum policy risks undermining the Northern Ireland peace accord.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Supreme Court of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Migrants are brought ashore after being picked up in the English Channel last week in Dover, England.

item.title: Israel Releases Videos It Says Show Hamas Tunnels Under Al-Shifa Hospital
item.description: Israeli and American officials have said that Hamas uses hospitals for cover. Hamas and administrators of Al-Shifa, Gaza’s largest hospital, have denied the claims.
item.dc:creator: Nadav Gavrielov

item.title: Israel-Hamas Pause in Fighting May Start Friday at Earliest
item.description: Both sides announced a four-day pause in the war between Israel and Hamas, but details were still being worked out.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Ronen Bergman and Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: Photographs of hostages in Ramat Gan, Israel, on Wednesday.

item.title: Cameron Ortis Found Guilty of Providing Secrets to Criminals
item.description: A jury convicted Cameron Ortis, who defended himself by arguing that he was engaged in a secret mission when he sought to sell secrets.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Sean Kilpatrick/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Cameron Ortis arriving at court this month in Ottawa. Prosecutors are seeking over 20 years in prison.

item.title: Far-Right Party Predicted to Win Dutch Elections in Landslide
item.description: The party of Geert Wilders, a longtime political provocateur with a history of antipathy toward immigrants and Islam, held a wide lead, according to early results, an outcome that could send shock waves through Europe.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Geert Wilders, the leader of the Party for Freedom, speaking after the first preliminary results of general elections on Wednesday in The Hague, Netherlands.

item.title: Student’s Killing Pushes Italy to Confront Violence Against Women
item.description: The case of Giulia Cecchettin, found dead days before she would have graduated, has prompted an outpouring of rage and debate on how to shift an entrenched culture of chauvinism.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: A vigil in Milan for Giulia Cecchettin, 22, who was missing for a week before her body was found in a ditch.

item.title: Deal to Free Child Hostages in Gaza Inspires Hope and Anguish
item.description: Some or all of the at least 36 children taken to the enclave as captives on Oct. 7 are expected to be freed. But the announcement raised anxieties about who might make it out.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protester at a march in Tel Aviv this month with a poster of Kfir Bibas, who has turned 10 months old while captive in Gaza.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Waiting for a Cease-Fire in Gaza
item.description: Plus Sam Altman is back at OpenAI.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Protesters rallied for the release of Palestinians being held in Israeli jails, and in support of Gaza, in Ramallah in the West Bank this month.

item.title: How the Israel-Hamas Hostage Deal Came Together
item.description: The agreement between Israel and Hamas required painful negotiations, but if carried out successfully, it could lead to the release of more hostages and extend the temporary cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A display in Tel Aviv of photos of Israeli citizens held hostage in Gaza. The deal is set to free 50 of the roughly 240 hostages.

item.title: U.S. Presses Israel to Set Up Safe Areas During Coming Pause in Gaza War
item.description: President Biden and his aides are trying to get Israel to take measures that would reduce Palestinian civilian deaths and restore services.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: U.S. and international concern is growing about the civilian deaths and humanitarian crisis in Gaza.

item.title: For Israeli Officials, a Long, Hard Path to a Truce With Hamas
item.description: For weeks, senior Israeli leaders were divided about whether a temporary cease-fire might help Hamas regroup and endanger the remaining hostages.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Patrick Kingsley, Adam Sella and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Palestinians searching for bodies and survivors amid the rubble in the Jabaliya neighborhood after an airstrike in northern Gaza this month.

item.title: Joan Jara, Who Found Justice for Husband Slain After Coup, Dies at 96
item.description: She sought accountability in the military killing of the leftist folk singer Victor Jara in the right-wing turmoil that carried Gen. Augusto Pinochet to power in Chile in 1973.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Ms. Jara posed in 2009 in front of a photo of her husband, Victor Jara, a leftist Chilean folk singer and songwriter who was rounded up with others the day after a military coup in Chile and shot 40 times by troops.

item.title: Putin Bristles as G20 Leaders Criticize Aggression in Ukraine
item.description: For Mr. Putin, it was a rare interaction with Western leaders since the start of the war last year. It was also the first time he had to listen to direct public criticism at an international event.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin speaking via video conference at the G20 summit from Moscow, in a photo released by Russian state media.

item.title: 1973: Israel Accepts Egypt’s Request on Small Issue
item.description: With the matter of the proper spelling of an Egyptian general’s surname settled, cease-fire talks proceeded.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: Giving Thanks When the World Is on Fire
item.description: This year, I cannot count my blessings without also counting the sorrows and fears that lurk in their shadows.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub

item.title: In Gaza, Deal for Temporary Cease-Fire Brings ‘Little Bit of Relief’
item.description: Residents of the enclave expressed hope about a pause in Israel’s bombardment but felt that the agreement would not bring an end to the war.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek and Abu Bakr Bashir
item.media:description: Searching for casualties at the site of a strike on a house in Rafah, in southern Gaza, on Wednesday.

item.title: In Israel, Families of Hostages Held in Gaza Wait Anxiously for News
item.description: Hours after the cease-fire deal was announced, some relatives of hostages held in Gaza said they had received no official information from the Israeli authorities.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner and Adam Sella
item.media:credit: Mads Claus Rasmussen/Ritzau Scanpix, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Family and friends of hostages at a news conference at Denmark’s Parliament in Copenhagen last month.
